chunks.en: How to find a programmer job starting from zero experience? This question might be a little ridiculous.
I have been unemployed for a long time and my personal financial situation is very bad.
I want to find a job with a relatively high salary.
May I ask: What skills do I need to have to most easily find a well-paid development job?
Can these skills be acquired through self-study? What is the general learning method?
Find a path on roadmap.sh and follow it to the end.
Your question only makes sense when there are more jobs than people.
But now there are fewer jobs than people, which means that you not only need to have the ability to work, but also need to surpass other applicants with the ability to work.

In other words, learning to the point where you can work is not enough. You need to have a degree and learn to the point where you can fake a few years of work experience without being exposed. The learning cycle will be very long and there will be many detours.
Most people can't stick to it at all, it's even more difficult than delivering food.
Delivering food is hard work, not difficult, you don't have to use your brain, and the income is visible.
But learning to program may not give you any feedback before you find a job. This state is not suitable for people who are long-term unemployed and in poor financial condition.
It may be a walled city. Mental work is not necessarily easy, and you may have to deal with various chores outside of work, which can be tiring.

Furthermore, I personally believe that this profession requires continuous learning to maintain one's own advantages in the market. Perhaps you need to be able to accept the situation where you have to take time to study after get off work.
I think it is still difficult to switch to coding with zero experience. Fresh graduates from formal programs are already very saturated.
In contrast, you also need to have other advantages, be more willing to spend time learning than others, invest more working hours, and have excellent communication skills.
Anyway, good luck.

chunks.en: To be honest, if you find Windows difficult to use, then Linux is even more so (in fact, the OP has expressed in another post that Linux is not easy to use, and is unwilling to learn to use the command line).

chunks.zh: æœ€æ ¸å¿ƒçš„é—®é¢˜åœ¨äºï¼Œå½“ä»Šä¸–ç•Œçš„ IT åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½ä¸»è¦æ˜¯é  Linux æ”¯æ’‘çš„ï¼Œå…¶æ¬¡æ˜¯ Windows ã€‚
chunks.en: The core issue is that the world's IT infrastructure is mainly supported by Linux, followed by Windows.
Although there are many subdivisions of programmers, most programmers must be familiar with either Linux or Windows.

chunks.zh: å³ä½¿æ˜¯æƒ³åš ChromeOS å¼€å‘ï¼Œé‚£ä¹Ÿå¾—ç†Ÿæ‚‰ Linux ï¼Œé¡»çŸ¥é“ Chrome æœ¬èº«å°±æ˜¯åŸºäº Linux çš„ã€‚
chunks.en: Even if you want to do ChromeOS development, you have to be familiar with Linux, you must know that Chrome itself is based on Linux.
If you reject both of these systems at the same time, not only will the types of learning be narrow, but the types of employment will also be very narrow.
Not to mention the situation of zero experience. In the learning process, you will always encounter at least one of these two systems.

In the IT industry, especially for programmers, living in the comfort zone for a long time will lead to becoming more and more out of date, and the risk of elimination (the chance of layoffs) will become higher and higher.
What's more, it is even more taboo to have a comfort zone when you have zero experience and have not even started.

Specifically, it is this mentality: for knowledge outside the comfort zone, you can't learn this, you find that difficult, and then you develop a resistance, you don't even want to learn, let alone improve. This mentality will lead to the inability to even get started.
Although there are many people on V Station who are not interested in or directly reject some technologies, that is because they are experienced and can accurately point out fundamental shortcomings.
V Station's latest example: /t/1015740
With zero experience, you don't have this kind of experience and sensitivity. Rejecting things based on your comfort zone will not only lead to detours, but will also become a roadblock.

If you really want to get started with zero experience, it is best to return to the state you were in when you just graduated from high school, and treat IT knowledge (including the skilled use of the two major systems) with an "exploratory" attitude, instead of rejecting this and rejecting that.

Otherwise, even if you bite the bullet and learn it, you still won't be able to compete with young graduates (especially in the current situation of strong "involution", youth is their advantage), let alone compete with experienced programmers of the same age.
The market is not very good now, and the lecturers of programming education training institutions are about to lose their jobs. You should consider this situation.

You can definitely master the relevant skills through self-study, but I'm afraid the company will not pass your skills when screening people, such as looking at your education, age, etc. If it doesn't work, they won't send you an interview directly.

If you have to learn, then the following is the path: go to recruitment software (such as boss direct recruitment) to see the local positions, don't care about those particularly high-paying positions, such as infrastructure, algorithms, etc. This kind of keyword represents particularly high requirements, you just find java development.

chunks.zh: ç„¶åå» bilibili ä¸Šæœç´¢ java çš„è¯¾ç¨‹ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚é»‘é©¬å’Œå°šç¡…è°·çš„è§†é¢‘ï¼Œè·Ÿç€å­¦å°±è¡Œäº†ï¼Œç„¶åçœ‹é‚£äº› java å²—ä½è¿˜éœ€è¦ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Œéœ€è¦ä»€ä¹ˆå­¦ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ redis ï¼Œä½ å†æœ redis è§†é¢‘ï¼Œè·Ÿç€å­¦å°±è¡Œäº†
chunks.en: Then go to bilibili to search for java courses, such as the videos of Heima and Shang Silicon Valley, and follow them to learn. Then see what else those java positions need, learn whatever you need, such as redis, then search for redis videos and follow them to learn.
You get all the benefits... There is no such a good thing.
What are you willing to give?
There is a paradox here. The effort required to go from zero experience to finding a decent-paying programmer job is much greater than the difficulty of finding other jobs.
And if you put these efforts into other industries and positions, you don't need to be a programmer.
First make a living, then plan.

chunks.en: Continued: 1. Front-end direction (relatively easy to get started, less knowledge to learn, mainly html, css, JavaScript, and then learn a framework, such as vue, now with the help of GPT, it should be easy to learn) 2. Back-end direction (more knowledge involved, at least you need to learn database (mysql) + a back-end language, such as php, go, java, etc.)
@hubqin Software testing is indeed a good suggestion.

There is a large demand for software testers [although the absolute number is not as large as software development positions], but few people are willing to do it, so the result is that the actual recruitment requirements for "software testing positions" are far lower than "software development positions".
Therefore, software testing is more suitable for short-term learning through various materials and intensive work positions.

chunks.zh: è€Œä¸”,  è½¯ä»¶æµ‹è¯• æ‰€éœ€è¦æŒæ¡çš„å†…å®¹å’Œæ€æƒ³ ä¹Ÿæ¯” è½¯ä»¶å¼€å‘ è¦å°‘ä¸æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°é‡çº§å§.
chunks.en: Moreover, the content and ideas that software testing needs to master are also less than software development.
Moreover, software testing positions are very likely to be in a situation of "more positions than applicants", while software development positions are the opposite.
You have been unemployed for a long time and originally had plenty of time to study on your own, but you are still at zero experience.
You are just coming for the high salary, you have no passion and are not willing to give anything. Why should the company want you?
In the past few years, many people like you have entered the industry during its prosperity, and I am glad that the industry has started to clear them out in the past two years.
Self-study, take your time.
I self-studied Python for four months in 2016.
Four months later, my first job was 2000 yuan, and the company was just the boss and me.
When I first learned, I didn't even know what windows cmd was.
I started earning above-average salaries in 2019.
Personal experience, self-study for a few months is enough, then go out to find a job, don't ask for a high salary, the main purpose is to find someone to lead you, gain experience and skills.
----------May I ask: What skills do I need to have to most easily find a well-paid development job? Can these skills be acquired through self-study? What is the general learning method?--------
Reply: 1. Have the ability to write code.
For example, if you want to find a web development job, then you need to be able to write web pages. If you want to work on servers and databases, then you need to learn servers and databases.
2. You can acquire it through self-study.
3. Books, videos, open courses, forums, communicate with people in the industry, find projects to do, find a job and learn while working.
I used to have a friend who was not very good after IT training, but he could always find a job with a salary of 20,000 yuan after packaging himself well.
He can't pass the probation period , so he looks at the company's projects during the probation period and keeps asking the colleagues inside.

He was fired and then packaged himself into another company to learn until he completely learned and could survive the probation period, and then he stayed in this industry with a salary of hundreds of thousands a year. He said that he is now an architect.
@idragonet Similar to borrowing a graduate design from a fresh graduate.
Something simpler.
Anything is possible in your dreams.
On the contrary, physical labor occupations will become more and more popular in the future, because no one wants to suffer.

If you want to learn programming, then learn front-end development. Compared with back-end development, the front-end requires relatively less knowledge to learn and the learning cost is also lower than the back-end.
If you don't learn css and animation related things.
Then get an associate degree. A high school diploma is definitely not acceptable.
Then slowly get a bachelor's degree.
Now the involution is very serious, the supply exceeds the demand.
You are 30 years old. It's time to focus and work hard. You don't have a few years to waste.

@maguazhou Looking at the technical positions in small and medium-sized companies, the closest thing to zero experience is actually application testing positions, not white-box testing, but black-box testing, you can probably find a job if you know a little bit.
Nothing is impossible for a willing heart. ğŸº
The above are all persuading you to quit. I'll tell lz a highly feasible way out, which is to find an influential open source project and contribute!

Spend a few months learning this project thoroughly, and make yourself one of the main contributors to this project. It's best if this project is produced by a company or sponsored by a company. When you have the ability to become a major contributor to this project, someone will naturally recruit you.
Now focus all your energy on learning English, go abroad to study for a master's degree in CS, and then use the opportunity to study to find a job and stay.
